DataElement.preferredDefinition: A description of the immunohistochemical laboratory test.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: A diagnostic test in which an antibody is used to link a cellular antigen specifically to a stain that can be seen with a microscope._The words or language units by which a thing is known.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: B-Cell Lymphoma 6 Protein is a zinc finger transcription factor containing an N-terminal POZ domain. It acts as a sequence-specific repressor of transcription and its activity is dependent upon DNA-binding and on the N-terminal region containing the POZ motif. This protein can interact with a variety of POZ-containing proteins that function as transcription corepressors. Target genes have roles in B-cell activation, B-cell differentiation, inflammation, and cell cycle control. Expression of BCL6 in some B-cells early in the antigen response may skew them toward a germinal center fate, away from a plasma cell fate. The BCL6 gene is found to be frequently translocated and hypermutated in diffuse large-cell lymphoma (DLCL), and may be involved in the pathogenesis of DLCL. (from OMIM, LocusLink and NCI)

Concepts.definition: B-cell lymphoma 6 protein (706 aa, ~79 kDa) is encoded by the human BCL6 gene. This protein is involved in transcriptional repression, apoptosis regulation and cell cycle progression.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Low Affinity Immunoglobulin Epsilon Fc Receptor

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Low Affinity Immunoglobulin Epsilon Fc Receptor
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: : Low affinity immunoglobulin epsilon Fc receptor (321 aa, ~36 kDa) is encoded by the human FCER2 gene. This protein is involved in B cell differentiation and IgE production.

Concepts.longName: Low Affinity Immunoglobulin Epsilon Fc Receptor
Concepts.definition: Low affinity immunoglobulin epsilon Fc receptor (321 aa, ~36 kDa) is encoded by the human FCER2 gene. This protein is involved in B cell differentiation and IgE production.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Antigen KI-67 protein (3256 aa, ~359 kDa) is encoded by the human MKI67 gene. This protein is required for cell proliferation.

Concepts.definition: Antigen KI-67 protein (3256 aa, ~359 kDa) is encoded by the human MKI67 gene. This protein is required for cell proliferation.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: G1/S-specific cyclin-D1 (295 aa, ~34 kDa) is encoded by the human CCND1 gene. This protein is involved in the regulation of the G1/S transition of the cell cycle.

Concepts.definition: G1/S-specific cyclin-D1 (295 aa, ~34 kDa) is encoded by the human CCND1 gene. This protein is involved in the regulation of the G1/S transition of the cell cycle.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Integrin alpha-E (1179 aa, ~130 kDa) is encoded by the human ITGAE gene. This protein plays a role in cell adhesion and may be involved in activation of intestinal intraepithelial lymphocytes.

Concepts.definition: Integrin alpha-E (1179 aa, ~130 kDa) is encoded by the human ITGAE gene. This protein plays a role in cell adhesion and may be involved in activation of intestinal intraepithelial lymphocytes.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Leukosialin (400 aa, ~40 kDa) is encoded by the human SPN gene. This protein is involved in immune cell function.

Concepts.definition: Leukosialin (400 aa, ~40 kDa) is encoded by the human SPN gene. This protein is involved in immune cell function.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: B-lymphocyte antigen CD20 (297 aa, ~33 kDa) is encoded by the human MS4A1 gene. This protein plays a role in both the activation and proliferation of B-cells.

Concepts.definition: B-lymphocyte antigen CD20 (297 aa, ~33 kDa) is encoded by the human MS4A1 gene. This protein plays a role in both the activation and proliferation of B-cells.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A protein that helps control whether a cell lives or dies by blocking a type of cell death called apoptosis. The gene for BCL2 is found on chromosome 18, and transfer of the BCL2 gene to a different chromosome is seen in many B-cell leukemias and lymphomas. This causes the BCL2 protein to be made in larger amounts, which may keep cancer cells from dying.

Concepts.definition: This gene is involved in apoptotic regulation. Overexpression of this gene promotes the pathogenesis of B-Cell lymphomas, due to anti-apoptotic activity.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: ALK tyrosine kinase receptor (1620 aa, ~176 kDa) is encoded by the human ALK gene. This protein is involved in ligand binding, tyrosine phosphorylation and signal transduction.

Concepts.definition: ALK tyrosine kinase receptor (1620 aa, ~176 kDa) is encoded by the human ALK gene. This protein is involved in ligand binding, tyrosine phosphorylation and signal transduction.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Neprilysin (750 aa, ~86 kDa) is encoded by the human MME gene. This protein is involved in the metabolism of biologically active peptides.

Concepts.definition: Neprilysin (750 aa, ~86 kDa) is encoded by the human MME gene. This protein is involved in the metabolism of biologically active peptides.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Tumor Necrosis Factor Receptor Superfamily Member 8

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Tumor Necrosis Factor Receptor Superfamily Member 8
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Tumor necrosis factor receptor superfamily member 8 (595 aa, ~ 64 kDa) is encoded by the human TNFRSF8 gene. This protein is involved in ligand-mediated signal transduction, the positive regulation of apoptosis and the inhibition of cell proliferation.

Concepts.longName: Tumor Necrosis Factor Receptor Superfamily Member 8
Concepts.definition: Tumor necrosis factor receptor superfamily member 8 (595 aa, ~ 64 kDa) is encoded by the human TNFRSF8 gene. This protein is involved in ligand-mediated signal transduction, the positive regulation of apoptosis and the inhibition of cell proliferation.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: T-cell surface glycoprotein CD5 (495 aa, ~54 kDa) is encoded by the human CD5 gene. This protein may be involved in regulating the proliferation of T-cells.

Concepts.definition: T-cell surface glycoprotein CD5 (495 aa, ~54 kDa) is encoded by the human CD5 gene. This protein may be involved in regulating the proliferation of T-cells.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Interferon regulatory factor 4 (451 aa, ~52 kDa) is encoded by the human IRF4 gene. This protein is involved in the mediation of both T-cell activation and interferon-stimulated response element promoter-dependent gene expression.

Concepts.definition: Interferon regulatory factor 4 (451 aa, ~52 kDa) is encoded by the human IRF4 gene. This protein is involved in the mediation of both T-cell activation and interferon-stimulated response element promoter-dependent gene expression.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Paired box protein Pax-5 (391 aa, ~42 kDa) is encoded by the human PAX5 gene. This protein plays a role in B-cell differentiation, neural development, spermatogenesis and gene transcription.

Concepts.definition: Paired box protein Pax-5 (391 aa, ~42 kDa) is encoded by the human PAX5 gene. This protein plays a role in B-cell differentiation, neural development, spermatogenesis and gene transcription.

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Epstein-Barr Encoding Region in situ Hybridization

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Epstein-Barr Encoding Region in situ Hybridization
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Any of various in situ hybridization methods for the detection of latent Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) in tissue sections or other samples. The two small noncoding RNAs, Epstein-Barr encoding region (EBER)-1 and EBER-2, are ubiquitously expressed in all known EBV latency states.

Concepts.longName: Epstein-Barr Encoding Region in situ Hybridization
Concepts.definition: Any of various in situ hybridization methods for the detection of latent Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) in tissue sections or other samples. The two small noncoding RNAs, Epstein-Barr encoding region (EBER)-1 and EBER-2, are ubiquitously expressed in all known EBV latency states.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Any of various immunohistochemical procedures for visualizing and/or quantitating SOX11 transcription factor expression in a sample. Dysregulation of SOX11 is associated with several types of cancer and has diagnostic and prognostic value.

Concepts.definition: Any of various immunohistochemical procedures for visualizing and/or quantitating SOX11 transcription factor expression in a sample. Dysregulation of SOX11 is associated with several types of cancer and has diagnostic and prognostic value.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: c-Myc staining is a sensitive immunohistochemical method for studying the tissue localization of c-Myc protein using antibody followed by a microscopic observation of the c-Myc staining distribution. The technique is used to detect overexpression of c-Myc oncogene which leads to cancer.

Concepts.definition: c-Myc staining is a sensitive immunohistochemical method for studying the tissue localization of c-Myc protein using antibody followed by a microscopic observation of the c-Myc staining distribution. The technique is used to detect overexpression of c-Myc oncogene which leads to cancer.
